It feeds almost exclusively on coastal red, brown and green algae. Occasionally, animal food (mollusks, young crabs and amphipods) is also found in their stomachs. Spawning occurs in April-June, sometimes continuing into July. Females lay sticky eggs on the underside of coastal stones, or in the empty valves of bivalves (mussels and oysters). The male guards the egg laying for 15-20 days.

creatures.name: Zvonimir's blenny
creatures.text:
Zvonimir's blenny (Parablennius zvonimiri) is a species of percomorph marine fish of the family Blenniidae. This species reaches a length of 7 centimetres (2.8 in). Body length up to 7 cm. The body is elongated, low, laterally compressed. The dorsal fin, in which there are no more than 19 branched rays, with a noticeable notch between the anterior and posterior parts, meets the caudal fin. There are often several tentacles in the center of the front of the head. The tentacles look like long lobes that almost reach the beginning of the dorsal fin. The tentacles also have up to 7 finger-like sprouts and become thinner towards the apex. Behind the front nostrils there is a long lobe that reaches the rear nostrils and branches in the upper part into 2-3 sprouts. There are 29-34 teeth on the upper jaw, and 28-30 teeth on the lower jaw, the last tooth of both jaws is enlarged. The general color background is chocolate brownish. On the back and sides there are small dark spots that sometimes merge into stripes. There are up to 7 whitish or yellowish spots at the base of the dorsal fin, and a dark brown spot at the base of the caudal fin. Dark spots appear on the septa of the anterior part of the dorsal fin, on the front of the body and on the back of the head. During breeding, the color of the males becomes brighter.
Zvonimir's blenny is a bottom dwelling fish of coastal areas with a rocky bottom. It lives in small groups among rocks and large stones at depths of up to 5-6 m. Feeds on bottom fouling organisms.

creatures.name: Tentacled blenny
creatures.text:
The tentacled blenny (Parablennius tentacularis) is a species of percomorph marine fish of the family Blenniidae. This species reaches a length of 15 centimetres (5.9 in) but more common length is about 7-10 centimetres (2.8-3.9 in). The body is elongated, low, slightly laterally compressed. The dorsal fin has at least 20 branched rays; there is no notch between the anterior and posterior parts of the fin. The tentacles above the eyes are quite long (often reaching the beginning of the dorsal fin), thick and have massive outgrowths and fringe along the posterior edge. There are 24-29 teeth on the upper jaw, 21-25 teeth on the lower jaw, the outer teeth of both jaws are enlarged in the form of fangs. The general color background is brownish, grayish-yellowish or reddish. There are 6-7 transverse stripes or large and small spots on the sides. The dorsal fin is yellowish or grayish-yellowish, with a black spot at its beginning, the pectoral fins are yellowish, and the anal fin is gray.
The tentacled blenny is a demersal fish which can be found in the sand at the bottom of the water in light vegetation. It lives at a depth of 1-3 m, also occurring up to a depth of 25 m.

creatures.name: Mystery blenny
creatures.text:
The mystery blenny (Parablennius incognitus) is a species of percomorph marine fish of the family Blenniidae. It can reach a length of 6.5 centimetres (2.6 in). The body is elongated, low, slightly laterally compressed. The dorsal fin, in which there are no more than 19 branched rays, with a noticeable notch between the anterior and posterior parts, almost meets the caudal fin. There are often tentacles on the front of the head. The general color background is grayish-greenish, with up to 7-9 yellowish-brownish or brownish transverse stripes on the sides. During breeding, males acquire yellow, red, brown, green, etc. colors.
The mystery blenny is a bottom dwelling fish of coastal shallow rocky areas.It lives in small groups at depths of up to 0.5-2.5 m among rocks and large stones covered with algae, in which there are places to hide. It feeds on bottom invertebrates and partly algae.

creatures.name: Peacock blenny
creatures.text:
The peacock blenny (Salaria pavo) is a species of percomorph marine fish of the family Blenniidae. It reaches a length of 13 centimetres (5.1 in). Males are usually larger than females. The body is without scales, spindle-shaped, covered with a layer of thick mucus. The supraorbital projections are short and almost invisible. The front profile of the head is rounded; males have a crest running from the dorsal fin to the eyes in the form of a convex arc. The teeth are weak, mostly located in one row in the form of a comb, 26-32 teeth on the upper jaw, and 19-24 teeth on the lower jaw. The lateral line in the front of the body is located above, then curves over the end of the pectoral fin, then passes through the middle of the body. The color of males is brighter than females. In general, the coloration on top of the body is yellow-greenish, with 6-7 vertical stripes of bluish color and light blue dots on the sides and lines on top. Behind the eye there is a blackish spot, which is surrounded by a bluish rim and a ring of the same color. The crest on the head is yellowish in color, with a transverse dark green stripe. The dorsal and anal fin are greenish in color, with a lighter, brownish or bluish border.
The peacock blenny is found at shallow depths (mostly 30-50 cm) among stones and pebbles. It occurs near the coast almost all year round. It does not swim far from the chosen habitat. It moves like a snake, wriggling its entire body. It feeds on bottom invertebrates (preferring mollusks), crustaceans, eggs of other fish and algae.

creatures.name: Sphinx blenny
creatures.text:
The sphinx blenny (Aidablennius sphynx) is a species of percomorph marine fish of the family Blenniidae. It can measure up to 8 centimetres (3.1 in) long, common length is about 4 centimetres (1.6 in). The body is elongated, the caudal fin is rounded. The dorsal fin is long, starting just behind the head and ending at the caudal peduncle. Its spiny part is very high, and is separated from the soft part by a notch. The anal fin is similar to the soft part of the dorsal fin. The gill membranes on both sides are connected to each other, forming a fold above the interbranchial space. The head is small, the upper edge is rounded, the snout is blunt, the mouth is small with wide lips. The eyes are located in the upper part of the head, above each there is a small growth-tentacle. Females have weak teeth, arranged in one comb-like row. The color is beige-olive, grayish-green, the back is darker. The upper edge of the dorsal fin is smoky, the anal fin is yellow-brown with a dark edging, the pectoral fins are yellowish or gray-yellow with two transverse brown stripes and reddish rays. The caudal fin is reddish with two or three transverse dark stripes. Males' tentacles turn orange during spawning. On the sides there are 6-7 wide transverse greenish-brown stripes bordered by narrow blue stripes. The same narrow blue, but short stripes, and small spots are on the head.
The sphinx blenny is a bottom-dwelling fish that is found in the littoral zone near the shore among stones and rocks overgrown with green algae. They feed primarily on benthic algae, weeds and invertebrates.

creatures.name: Red-black triplefin
creatures.text:
The red-black triplefin (Tripterygion tripteronotum) is a species of fish in the family Tripterygiidae, the threefin blennies. The greatest body length is 6.7 cm, usually the length of females is up to 5.2 cm, males - up to 6.7 cm. Life expectancy is about 5 years. The body is elongated, low, laterally compressed, covered with ctenoid scales, small in the caudal part. Head, gill covers, bases of paired fins, ventral side to cloaca without scales. There are 3 dorsal fins, they are connected to each other by thin leathery membranes, the anal fin is very long. The head is small and convex. Above the large eyes, which are located on the upper edge of the head, there are short thread-like tentacles, and along the upper edge of the eyes there are short cilia. The color is very variable. The general background is red or gray with faint black or dark brown transverse stripes (up to 5 stripes) and spots. In males, the color is somewhat brighter: the head, belly, base of the paired fins are black, the pectoral, dorsal and anal fins are red, the dorsal fins have a bluish stripe and black dots. In females, the color of the body and head is usually brownish-pink, the belly, the rays of the paired fins are yellowish-white, the first dorsal fin is red, the other two are pinkish with four black stripes, and there are three dark transverse stripes on the caudal fin.
The red-black triplefin is a bottom sedentary fish of the coastal zone. It usually lives in pairs among large stones and rocks, where it finds refuge in burrows and caves, protected from bright light and surf. Adults feed on small benthic creatures, mainly crustaceans and amphipods, and also consume eggs and larvae of fish, in particular blennies.

creatures.name: Blunt-snouted mullet
creatures.text:
The blunt-snouted mullet (Mullus barbatus ponticus) is a species of the family Mullidae. It can grow to a length of 30 cm (12 in), but more common length is about half that. The body is somewhat laterally compressed. The head is large with a steeply sloping, almost vertical snout and high-set eyes. The small mouth is equipped with small bristle teeth. There are no spines on the operculum. It has two dorsal fins. A pair of moderately long barbels on the chin do not exceed the pectoral fins in length. They are sensory organs and are used to help locate prey. There are two types of coloring. First type: the back is pale pink with dark spots, at eye level there is an intermittent burgundy-brown longitudinal stripe, the sides are silver with large red spots, including on the head. Second type: the back is silver-gray, at eye level there is a burgundy-brown longitudinal stripe, the sides are white-gray with a yellow longitudinal stripe. The fins in both variants are light yellow or colorless.
The blunt-snouted mullet is a demersal fish and occurs at depths ranging from 15 to 300 m (49 to 984 ft) over muddy, sandy or gravel bottoms. It is carnivorous, the diet consisting mainly of polychaete worms, bivalve molluscs and crustaceans. Both young and adult mullet are preyed on by various fish including the angler fish (Lophius piscatorius), the thornback ray (Raja clavata), the common stingray (Dasyatis pastinaca) and the European hake (Merluccius merluccius).

creatures.name: Sailfin dragonet
creatures.text:
The sailfin dragonet (Callionymus pusillus) is a species of the family Callionymidae. This species grows to a length of 14 centimetres (5.5 in) while females reach a length of 10 centimetres (3.9 in). The body is elongated, low, without scales, the head and front part of the body are flattened, the back part is laterally compressed. The sailfin dragonet has three upwardly directed spines on the preoperculum and differs from other species of dragonet by having a first dorsal fin which is lower than the second dorsal fin. The second dorsal fin has long rays which extend into long filaments. These filaments extend beyond the caudal fin. The male is brightly coloured with 14 to 16 silvery transverse lines fringed with black on its body and with blue streaks on the fins. The female is beige with small whitish spots.
It is a benthic species which occurs in shallow waters and prefers sandy bottoms down to 100 metres (330 ft). The males are territorial, aggressively defend their territories from other males. This species feeds mainly on small benthic invertebrates such as worms and small crustaceans.

creatures.name: Mediterranean horse mackerel
creatures.text:
The Mediterranean horse mackerel (Trachurus mediterraneus), also known as the Black Sea horse mackerel, Mediterranean scad or common scad, is a species of mackerel in the family Carangidae. It has an elongated, compressed body (up to 60 cm (24 in) in length, common length 30 cm (12 in)) with a large head and projected lower jaw. The nostrils are small and close-set and the eyes are protected by a well-developed adipose eyelid. Its upper jaw, or maxilla, is also large and wide. Its body is a dusky color, blue to grey to black in color dorsally and on top of the head, while the lower two-thirds of the body is white to silver in color. Its caudal fin is yellow and it has a distinct black mark just posterior to the operculum. It has 36-41 gillrakers and the anal fin is preceded by two separate spines.
Mediterranean horse mackerel is a marine species that prefers brackish water. Its typical depth range is 5-250 m (16-820 ft), though it can be found as deep as 500 m (1,600 ft). It lives near the bottom, though it sometimes schools near the surface. It feeds primarily on sardines, anchovies, and small crustaceans.

creatures.name: European angler
creatures.text:
The European angler (Lophius piscatorius), commonly known as the common monkfish, is a monkfish in the family Lophiidae. Body length - up to 2 m, more often about 1 m. Maximum weight 57.7 kg. It has a very large head which is broad, flat, and depressed; the rest of the body appears to be a mere appendage. The wide mouth extends all the way around the anterior circumference of the head, and both jaws are armed with bands of long, pointed teeth. These are inclined inwards and can be closed so as to offer no impediment to an object gliding towards the stomach, but to prevent its escape from the mouth. The pectoral and pelvic fins are articulated as to perform the functions of feet, so the fish is able to walk along the bottom of the sea, where it generally hides in the sand or amongst seaweed. Around its head and also along the body, the skin bears fringed appendages resembling short fronds of seaweed, a structure which, combined with the ability to match the colour of the body to its surroundings, assists this fish in camouflaging itself in the places which it selects on account of the abundance of prey. It has no scales.
The fish has long filaments along the middle of its head, which are, in fact, the detached and modified three first spines of the anterior dorsal fin. The filament most important to the angler is the first, which is the longest, terminates in a lappet, and is movable in every direction. The angler is believed to attract other fish by means of its lure, and then to seize them with its enormous jaws. While it is considered probable that smaller fish are attracted in this way experiments have shown that the actions of the jaw is automatic and depends on the contact of the prey with the tentacle. Its stomach is expandable and it is not unknown for these fish to swallow prey of their own size.
The European angler inhabits muddy and sandy bottoms up to depths of 1,000 metres (3,300 ft). It is occasionally found on rocky bottoms as well. Adult anglers feed primarily on fish, while juveniles prey mainly on marine invertebrates.

creatures.name: Painted comber
creatures.text:
The painted comber (Serranus scriba) is a species of marine ray-finned fish, a sea bass from the subfamily Serraninae, classified as part of the family Serranidae. The maximum recorded fish measurement is 36 centimetres (14 in), although 25 centimetres (9.8 in) is more typical. It has a laterally compressed, elongate body with a pointed snout. The dorsal fin has 10 spines and 4-16 soft rays and the anal fin has 3 spines and 7-8 soft rays. The caudal fin is truncate. It has a very large mouth for its size, which has many sharp teeth, and is protractile. The overall colour may be grey, purplish or reddish with 5-7 dark brown bars on the flanks. The head is marked with many narrow, wavy blue lines and red blotches. The dorsal, anal and caudal fins are marked with red dots. There is a diffuse, purplish-blue blotch in the middle of the body. The pelvic and pectoral fins are normally uniform pale yellow.
The painted comber occurs over rocky bottom and among beds of Posidonia at depths of 5 to 150 metres (16 to 492 ft). It normally spends the day sheltering in rocky caves and is normally either solitary or found in small groups. It emerges at dusk to hunt. It is a carnivorous species which is a territorial ambush hunter and has a diet made up of cephalopods, bivalves, crustaceans, fishes, and worms.

creatures.name: Greater weever
creatures.text:
The greater weever (Trachinus draco) is a benthic and demersal venomous marine fish of the family Trachinidae. The body dimensions are described very differently by different authors and seem to differ based on the geographical location were the study has been carried out. In the Eastern Black Sea, the length distribution of mature fishes ranges from 10 cm up to a maximum of 25.8 cm for females and from 9.5 cm to 22.5 cm for males. The weight ranges from 6.96 g to 131.76 g for females and from 5.34 g to 75.84 g for males.
The greater weever is an elongated and laterally flattened fish with upstanding eyes and a distinct superior mouth that is inclined upwards. The lower jaw is longer than the upper jaw. The head is compact flat and relatively big and the eyes sit almost on top of it. The upper rim of the eye has two to three small spines, in front of each eye. The five to seven spiny fin rays on its first dorsal fin and the thorns on each of the gill covers have venom glands at their basis. This spines can inflict serious injuries on humans through accidental stinging. On the dorsal side it is coloured in an greenish brown with a varying count of dark marks on the upper side of the head. The flank is hued in a yellowish brown with bright blue and yellow discontinuous stripes that run crooked to the front of the fish. Additionally oblique black stripes can be found laterally.
This fish has been shown to occur in depths ranging from shallow water where it inhabits mostly muddy or sandy grounds. It is a so-called ambush predator that digs itself into fine sand during daytime only with its eyes and the tip of the dorsal fin exposed. There it lurks until prey emerges which is then attacked. It is a carnivore that mainly feeds on Decapods and Mysids. To a lower extent their diet contains also Isopoda, Amphipoda, Cephalopoda and Shells (Bivalvia). The most common prey that could be identified to the rank of species, were decapods namely Sandy swimming crab (Liocarcinus depurator) and mysids.

creatures.name: Black Sea salmon
creatures.text:
The Black Sea salmon (Salmo trutta labrax) or Black Sea trout is a fairly small species of the family Salmonidae, at about 51 cm (20 in) long on average and rarely reaching over 76 cm (30 in). Life expectancy is 10 years or more. The body is elongated and thick. There is an adipose fin on top of the caudal peduncle. The caudal fin has a barely noticeable notch. The head is not large, wedge-shaped. The mouth is large, the upper jaw reaches the posterior edge of the eye. The dorsal surface is dark gray, the sides and belly are silvery. Small dark spots are located above and below the lateral line, as well as on the gill covers. The dorsal and caudal fins are dark, the anal and paired fins are grayish.
The Black Sea salmon goes into rivers to spawn. Spawning is usually in the fall, but sometimes occurs in January-March. In the second or third year of life, the juveniles migrate to the sea. At sea, it feeds on fish and invertebrates.

creatures.name: Bluefish
creatures.text:
The bluefish (Pomatomus saltatrix) is the only extant species of the family Pomatomidae. Adult bluefish are typically between 20 and 60 cm (8 in. to 2 ft.) long, with a maximum reported size of 120 cm (4 ft.) and 14 kg (31 lb). It is a moderately proportioned fish, with a broad, forked tail. The spiny first dorsal fin is normally folded back in a groove, as are its pectoral fins. Its single row of teeth in each jaw is uniform in size, knife-edged, and sharp. Coloration is a grayish blue-green dorsally, fading to white on the lower sides and belly.
The bluefish is found in pelagic waters on much of the continental shelves. Adult bluefish are strong and aggressive, and live in loose groups. They are fast swimmers that prey on schools of forage fish, and continue attacking them in feeding frenzies even after they appear to have eaten their fill. Depending on area and season, they favor sardine-like fish, mackerel, anchovies and shrimp. They are cannibalistic and can destroy their own young.

creatures.name: Black Sea turbot
creatures.text:
The Black Sea turbot or kalkan (Scophthalmus maeoticus) is a fish species in the family Scophthalmidae. The maximum body length is 85 cm, and the weight is 12 kg. The width of the body is almost equal to the length or even greater. The body is covered with bony conical tubercles. The fish's eyes are on its left (upper) side. The lower part (right side) is white, the eye side is brownish, with reddish spots. The fish has no scales. It also has the ability to change color for camouflage depending on the color of the bottom. The jaws are armed with smooth, bristle-like teeth arranged in the form of ribbons.
The Black Sea turbot prefers sandy (shell) and silty soils and inhabits them to depths of over 100 m. In winter and summer it stays in deeper water, in spring and autumn it moves to shallow water. The adult kalkan feeds mainly on small fish (blunt-snouted mullet, european anchovy, horse mackerel, Black Sea sprat) and crabs, while juveniles feed mainly on crustaceans.

creatures.name: Scaldback
creatures.text:
Scaldback (Arnoglossus kessleri) is a species of flatfish belonging to the family Bothidae. Maximum body length 10 cm. The body is oval-oblong, relatively high, strongly compressed laterally. The entire body is covered with rather large, easily falling scales, which extend to the head, with the exception of the jaws and areas around the nostrils. Both eyes are on the left side of the head. The teeth on the jaws are small in size, without fangs. The dorsal fin begins before eye level, its anterior rays are not elongated. The 10 anterior rays are folded in a calm state on the blind (right) side of the body. The paired fins on the left side are longer than those on the right side. The pelvic fins are located at the very end of the promontory. The color of the eye side is grayish-yellowish with small black dots and spots on the head, body and rays of unpaired fins. The blind side is light.
Scaldback lives in the bottom layers of the shelf zone near the sea coast at the bottom. It is found at depths from 3 to 65 m (usually about 20 m). Prefers sandy and sandy-pebble soils. Winters at depth. Spawning lasts from June to mid-September in the coastal zone at a depth of 3-7 m. Females lay eggs on the bottom. The eggs float into the water column, where they develop. As the fry grow and develop, their body transforms from the usual shape for fish to a form in which the left side becomes upper and both eyes move to the left side of the head. This is accompanied by a transition from pelagic to benthic lifestyle and nutrition from planktonic to benthic.

creatures.name: Common sole
creatures.text:
The common sole or black sole (Solea solea) is a species of flatfish in the family Soleidae. It is one of the largest fish in the Solea genus. It grows to a maximum length of about 70 cm (28 in). The small eyes are close to each other on the right side of the body. This gives the fish the possibility of lurking half-buried in the sand for passing prey. The common sole, just like all other flatfishes, hatches as an 'ordinary' fish with one eye on each side of the body. The young metamorphose to flatfish when they are about one centimeter long. The upper side is greyish-brown and the underside is white.
The common sole has a preference for relatively shallow water (10-60 m) with sand or mud covering the bottom. They also can be found at depths up to 200 m. Their preferred temperature range is from 8-24 °C. It feeds at night. Its diet consists of worms, molluscs and crustaceans.

creatures.name: Atlantic bonito
creatures.text:
The Atlantic bonito (Sarda sarda) is a large mackerel-like fish of the family Scombridae. Atlantic bonito grow up to 85 centimetres (33.5 in) and weigh 5-6 kilograms (11-13 lb) at this size. It belongs to a group in which the dorsal fins are very close together or separated by a narrow gap. Its body is completely scaled, with those scales in the pectoral fin area and the lateral line usually larger in size. The mouth is quite large and wide. The upper jaw reaches the posterior edge of the eye. The teeth are small, conical, arranged in one row. The palatine bones have strong conical single-row teeth. There are 16-26 teeth on the upper jaw, and 12-24 teeth on the lower jaw. The first dorsal fin has 20-23 spiny rays, and the second has 14-17 soft rays. The edge of the first dorsal fin is almost straight. Behind the second dorsal fin there is a row of 8 small fins. The pectoral fins are short, formed by 23-26 rays. The anal fin has 13-16 soft rays. Behind the anal fin there is a row of 7 small fins. The caudal peduncle is narrow. Atlantic bonito can be distinguished from its relatives by its dark oblique stripes on the back and with a maxillary only about half as long as the head. The back is blue-green, the sides and belly are silvery, the upper half of the body is covered with 5-12 narrow dark longitudinal stripes.
The Atlantic bonito is a strong swimmer. Normally, it travels in fairly large schools. The diet is based on small schooling pelagic fish. These fish are capable of swallowing quite large prey. Cannibalism is common.

creatures.name: Red gurnard
creatures.text:
The red gurnard (Chelidonichthys cuculus), also known as the East Atlantic red gurnard or soldier, is a benthic species of ray-finned fish belonging to the family Triglidae. This fish has a maximum published total length of 70 cm (28 in), although a fork length of 27.6 cm (10.9 in) in males and 20.4 cm (8.0 in) in females is more typical. It has a large angular head which does not have a deep occipital groove but has a steep snout, which is elongated forward with a flattened, two lobed rostrum covered in denticles. The first dorsal fin contains 9 or 10 spines, the first of which is serrated to the front and the second spine is not elongated. the second dorsal fin has 17 or 19 soft rays while the anal fin contains between 16 and 18 soft rays. The pectoral fins have 2 or 3 enlarged, separate rays. The scales in the lateral line resemble plates having been lengthened vertically. There are no scales on the breast and the front part of the belly. The colour is bright red on the upper body, pale on the lower body with pink pelvic fins. The anal fin is white at its base while the pectoral and dorsal fins are yellowish.
The red gurnard is a demersal species which has been recorded from depths between 15 and 400 m (49 and 1,312 ft), although the usual range is 30 and 250 m (98 and 820 ft). It is typically recorded on habitats dominated by sand or gravel, although it has also been found in rocky and muddy habitats. It feeds almost entirely on malacostracan crustaceans with fishes, molluscs and sea cucumbers taken in much smaller amounts. Prey is detected using the enlarged, separated rays of the pectoral fins. This species produces sounds, being noted to croak like a frog. It sometimes aggregates in schools, and it is known to spawn in the summer.

creatures.name: European seabass
creatures.text:
The European seabass (Dicentrarchus labrax), also known as the European bass, sea bass, common bass, white bass, capemouth, white salmon, sea perch or white mullet is a fish of the family Moronidae. It is a slow-growing species that takes several years to reach adulthood. An adult European seabass usually weighs around 2.5 kg (5.5 lb). It can reach measurements of up to 1 m (3 ft 3 in) in length and 12 kg (26 lb) in weight, though the most common size is only about half of that at 0.5 m (1 ft 8 in). The body is elongated, somewhat laterally compressed, covered with large scales. There are two dorsal fins, the first dorsal fin has 8-9 spiny rays, and the second has one spiny ray and 12-14 soft rays. The anal fin has 3 spiny and 10-13 soft rays. Caudal fin with a small notch. Individuals are silvery grey and sometimes a dark-bluish color on the back.
The European seabass is a marine pelagic fish. It lives in coastal waters at a depth of 10-100 m. Spawns from February to June in open waters far from the shore. It hunts as much during the day as it does at night, feeding on small fish, polychaetes, and crustaceans. The big fish weighing more than 4 kg (8.8 lb) are mostly night hunters.

creatures.name: Grass goby
creatures.text:
The grass goby (Zosterisessor ophiocephalus) is a species of the family Gobiidae. It can grow up to 25 cm (9.8 in) long. Top of the head, throat, belly, and bases of the pectoral fins are covered by cycloid scales and the gill covers are naked. The lower jaw protrudes forward. The skin is soft, with mucus. Their coloration is green-brown, patterned with merging brown spots. The cheeks have round light spots. The dorsal, caudal, and pectoral fins have longitudinal brown stripes on a light background; the anal and abdominal suckers are dark.
The grass goby lives in coastal waters with a high salinity range. Until it reaches two years of age, it eats only small crustaceans (like gammarids). After this it starts to eat fish and shrimps. Some predatory fish, including the large knout goby, feed on grass goby, and the Black Sea bottlenose dolphin also feeds on it.

creatures.name: Round goby
creatures.text:
The round goby (Neogobius melanostomus) is a species of fish of the family Gobiidae. It ranges in length from 10 to 25 centimetres (4 to 10 inches), with a maximum size of 24.6 cm (9.7 in). It weighs between 5.0 and 79.8 grams (0.176 and 2.816 ounces), its weight increasing with age. Males are larger than females. Round goby is a soft-bodied fish characterized by a distinctive black spot on the first dorsal fin. The eyes are large and protrude slightly from the top of the head and, like most gobies, the pelvic fins are fused to form a single disc (shaped like a suction cup) on the belly. Juvenile round gobies (less than one year old) are grey. Upon maturation, round gobies become mottled with grey, black, brown, and olive green markings. Adult male round gobies turn inky black during the spawning season and develop swollen cheeks.
The round goby is a euryhaline bottom-dwelling species. It is commonly found on continental shelves with sandy and rocky bottoms with low silting at depths from 1-2 m (3.3-6.6 ft) to 10-17 m (33-56 ft). It actively feeds both nocturnally and diurnally and is believed to detect prey only while stationary. The primary diet of round gobies includes mollusks, crustaceans, worms, fish eggs, small fish, insect larvae, and other small invertebrates (insects and amphipods) living on the bottom.

creatures.name: Transparent goby
creatures.text:
The transparent goby (Aphia minuta) is a species of the goby of the family Gobiidae. Maximum body length 7.9 centimetres (3.1 in). Life expectancy 1 year. The body is elongated, rather low, noticeably laterally compressed. The head, back to the beginning of the dorsal fin, flanks and caudal peduncle are covered with cycloid scales, which easily fall off the body when touched. The mouth is large, the teeth on the jaws are small, conical, arranged in one row. During life, almost the entire body is transparent, light, sometimes somewhat reddish. Adults have small black dots on the lips, on the top of the middle of the head, on the chin and in front of the ventral fins below, and at the base of the dorsal fins there are black-green spots; along the middle of the body there are yellow-greenish-reddish dots, along the anal fin there are red-brownish dots, along the rays of the caudal fin there are red dots.
The transparent goby inhabits inshore waters. It can be found at depths of from the surface to 97 metres (318 ft), though it is usually found at 5 to 80 metres (16 to 262 ft), over sandy and muddy bottoms and also in eelgrass beds. It feeds on zooplankton, preferring crustaceans.

creatures.name: Giant goby
creatures.text:
The giant goby (Gobius cobitis) is a species of goby of the family Gobiidae. It grows to 27 centimetres (11 in) in length. It is greyish to olive brown with 'pepper and salt' markings. These are especially notable in smaller specimens. Dark blotches appear along and below the lateral midline. The edges of the dorsal, tail and anal fins are light greyish in colour. The body is covered in small scales. Scales on top of the head do not extend to the level of the eyes. Upper rays of pectoral fin free of membrane. The tail stalk is short. The eyes are small.
The giant goby lives in coastal marine and brackish waters at depths of from 10 to 35 metres (33 to 115 ft). It prefers rock pools high up in the intertidal zone of sheltered shores. Occupied pools typically contain boulders under which the giant goby can take shelter, and have inputs of freshwater, so the water in the pools is usually brackish. This species has been recorded to feed upon polychaete worms, green algae, amphipods, crabs and insects.

creatures.name: Rock goby
creatures.text:
The rock goby (Gobius paganellus) is a small coastal goby of the family Gobiidae. It can reach a length of 12 centimetres (4.7 in) and has been known to live for ten years. It is usually black with white blotches, but they can change color, and males are much more black when guarding the eggs. The neck area lacks scales and there is a pale band on the top of the first dorsal fin. Both dorsal fins lack black spots on their leading edges.
The rock goby prefers rocky sea floors below the low tidemark, although it can be found in larger rock pools in Summer. It may also live in fresh or brackish water. It can be found at depths of from 0 to 15 metres (0 to 49 ft). It eats small crabs and amphipods, polychaetes, larva, small fish, copepods and mites.
The rock goby reproduces in spring. It nests in rocky areas. Up to 7000 eggs are laid in a single layer under rocks and shells. The eggs are laid in a single layer (2.5 mm in height) and guarded aggressively by the male. The eggs hatch in about 19 days.

creatures.name: Soft-shell clam
creatures.text:
Soft-shell clams or sand gaper (Mya arenaria) are a species of edible saltwater clam, a marine bivalve mollusk in the family Myidae. It has a calcium carbonate shell that is thin and easily broken, hence the name 'soft-shells'. Shell length up to 13 cm. The shape of the shell is usually oval, somewhat elongated at the back, moderately convex. The color of the shell varies from off-white to yellowish.
This clam is found living approximately 7.6-20.3 cm (3-8 in) under the surface of the mud. They live buried in the sediment on tidal flats. It extends its paired siphons up to the surface; these draw in seawater, filter it for food, and expel it. The holes in the mud through which the water is drawn in and out can often be seen at low tide. Life expectancy is 10-12 years, maximum up to 28 years.

creatures.name: Mediterranean mussel
creatures.text:
The mediterranean mussel (Mytilus galloprovincialis) is a species of bivalve, a marine mollusc in the family Mytilidae. This animal grows up to 140 mm in length. It is a smooth-shelled mussel with quite broad base. Its shell is blue-violet or black, but may shade to light brown.
The mediterranean mussel is a filter feeder. It is rare subtidally. They are generally considered as a bioindicators of the whole ecosystem in which they live. The immune system of bivalve molluscs is often chosen as a target parameter to evaluate the welfare of the species and of their surrounding environment. The immune systems of the mediterranean mussels are influenced by changing environmental parameters such as water acidification, temperature increases and variations in seawater salinity. Mussel colonies have a positive impact on the ecological state of the area. They not only destroy “marine debris” and clean the bottom, but also filter sea water, passing it through themselves. They are also one of the food sources for the local marine fauna.

creatures.name: Veined rapa whelk
creatures.text:
Veined rapa whelk (Rapana venosa), also known as asian rapa whelk, is a species of large predatory sea snail, a marine gastropod mollusc or whelk, in the family Muricidae, the rock shells. The shell of veined rapa whelk is globose (rounded) and heavy, possessing a very short spire, a large body whorl, a strong columella and a deep umbilicus. The aperture is large and roughly ovate. Ornamentation is present externally as axial ribs, smooth spiral ribs ending in blunt knobs at both the shoulder and body whorl, and internally as small elongated teeth disposed along the outer lip margin. The external color varies from gray to reddish-brown, with dark brown dashes on the spiral ribs. Some specimens may have distinctive black/dark blue vein-like coloration patterns throughout the inner portions of the shell, usually originating from each individual tooth at the outer lip. A diagnostic feature for this species is the deep orange color found in the aperture and on the columella. The height of the shell can reach up to 180 mm (about 7 in).
Veined rapa whelks favor compact sandy bottoms, in which they can burrow almost completely. The native habitat of this species is a region of wide annual temperature ranges, comparable to other localities. Fleeing cold waters in the winter, this species may migrate to warmer, deeper waters, thereby evading cool surface waters. This fertile sea snail is extremely versatile, tolerating low salinities, water pollution and oxygen deficient waters. Large specimens may be over ten years old.
Veined rapa whelks are carnivorous selective predatory gastropods whose main diet consists of a variety of other mollusk species, mainly epifaunal bivalves such as oysters and mussels, but also clams. Prey are chosen by the whelk according to their species and size. Most snails feed by drilling a hole into their bivalve prey, but rapa whelks usually smother their prey by wrapping around the hinged region of the shell and feed by introducing their proboscis between the opened valves. The whelk can also secrete a thick mucus that may or may not contain biotoxins to weaken the prey.

creatures.name: Netted dog-whelk
creatures.text:
The netted dog-whelk (Tritia reticulata) or netted nassa is a species of small European sea snail, a marine gastropod mollusc in the family Nassariidae. The length of the shell varies between 20 mm and 35 mm. The egg-shaped shell is elongated, rounded, obtuse at its lower extremity, and pointed at the upper extremity. It is moderately thick. The conical spire is composed of eight or nine whorls, almost flat, or slightly swollen, but distant from each other. Their surface is deeply chequered by longitudinal folds, crossed by numerous striae. The aperture is moderate, white and ovate. The outer lip is thick, ornamented within with seven or eight striae, of which those of the middle are generally the largest. The columella is slightly arcuated, covered with a thin, brilliant plate. The color of this shell is of a yellowish white, reddish or chestnut-color, with a blackish blue band, passing beneath the suture.
The netted dog-whelk is a widespread species that lives mainly on rocks, but is also found on sandy and silty soils. This species is characterized by a high degree of adaptability to environmental conditions. It easily tolerates both increases and decreases in water temperature and salinity ranging from 10 to 37 ppm. It is a scavenger, less often a predator, drilling through the thin-walled shells of bivalve mollusks. It also feeds on plants and detritus.

creatures.name: Barrel jellyfish
creatures.text:
The barrel jellyfish (Rhizostoma pulmo) or the dustbin-lid jellyfish, or the frilly-mouthed jellyfish, is a scyphomedusa in the family Rhizostomatidae. It typically is up to 40 cm (16 in) in diameter, but can exceptionally reach 150 cm (59 in) or larger. They have neither tentacles nor other structures at the bell's edges. Instead, they have eight highly branched oral arms, along which there are suctorial minimouth orifices. These oral arms become fused as they approach the central part of the jellyfish. The mouth of the animal is also subdivided into minute pores that are linked to coelenteron. The main source of food is planktonic organisms, which the jellyfish catch from the jet stream generated by the contraction of the bell and swallow through secondary oral openings on the oral lobes.
The barrel jellyfish is moderately venomous but not as deadly as other species. Effects include a burning sensation on the skin, dermatitis, and ulcers which confirms it is toxic to humans. However, it does not pose a serious threat to humans.

creatures.name: Common jellyfish
creatures.text:
Common jellyfish (Aurelia aurita) or moon jellyfish is a species of the family Ulmaridae. It is almost entirely translucent, usually about 25-40 cm (10-16 in) in diameter. The dome of a jellyfish is in the form of a round flat umbrella, along the edge of which there are numerous thin tentacles hanging down. The tentacles are studded with stinging cells that kill and paralyze small animals. When looking at the dome from above, you can see the stomach, consisting of four pockets and digestive canals radiating from it. Along the edge of the umbrella there are small cutouts with thickenings - marginal bodies (ropalia). They contain the main sensory organs of the jellyfish - the eyes and balance organs (statocysts). In the center of the lower concave part of the umbrella there is a quadrangular mouth, surrounded by four large oral lobes, shaped like donkey ears. The jellyfish respires by diffusing oxygen from water through the thin membrane covering its body. The large surface area membrane to volume ratio helps Aurelia diffuse more oxygen and nutrients into the cells.
Common jellyfish feeds by collecting medusae, plankton, and mollusks with its tentacles, and bringing them into its body for digestion. It is capable of only limited motion, and drifts with the current, even when swimming.
